<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 280, 171, 291]]<|/det|> # PHYSICS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 416, 311]]<|/det|> Paper 5 Planning, Analysis and Evaluation <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 341, 415, 352]]<|/det|> Candidates answer on the Question Paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 361, 369, 372]]<|/det|> No Additional Materials are required. <|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 394, 386, 405]]<|/det|> # READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 420, 718, 432]]<|/det|> Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 436, 327, 447]]<|/det|> Write in dark blue or black pen. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 451, 608, 463]]<|/det|> You may use a soft pencil for any diagrams, graphs or rough working. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 599, 478]]<|/det|> Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 481, 384, 492]]<|/det|> DO **NOT** WRITE IN ANY BARCODES. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 508, 256, 518]]<|/det|> Answer **all** questions. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 523, 765, 534]]<|/det|> You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 549, 603, 560]]<|/det|> At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 564, 753, 576]]<|/det|> The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 753, 905, 861]]<|/det|>

<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 75, 873, 107]]<|/det|>
As a bar magnet is dropped through a coil, an e.m.f. is induced in the coil. The maximum e.m.f. \(E\) is induced as the magnet leaves the coil with speed \(v\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 78, 944, 120]]<|/det|>
<form>Examiner's Use</FORM>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 120, 520, 136]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that \(E\) is directly proportional to \(v\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 152, 873, 199]]<|/det|>
Design a laboratory experiment to test the relationship between \(E\) and \(v\). You should draw a diagram, on page 3, showing the arrangement of your equipment. In your account you should pay particular attention to

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 212, 144, 230]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 212, 396, 228]]<|/det|>
the procedure to be followed,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 243, 144, 260]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 243, 415, 259]]<|/det|>
the measurements to be taken,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 274, 144, 292]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 274, 356, 290]]<|/det|>
the control of variables,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 305, 146, 323]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 305, 354, 321]]<|/det|>
the analysis of the data,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 336, 146, 354]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 336, 440, 352]]<|/det|>
the safety precautions to be taken.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[836, 352, 875, 370]]<|/det|>
<mark>[15]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 75, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 75, 875, 108]]<|/det|>
Different light-emitting diodes (LEDs) can emit electromagnetic radiation of different wavelengths.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 120, 875, 151]]<|/det|>
A student uses the circuit of Fig. 2.1 to investigate the minimum potential difference required to cause an LED to emit its characteristic wavelength.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[301, 165, 687, 448]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[462, 465, 528, 482]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 2.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 498, 875, 528]]<|/det|>
For different LEDs emitting radiation of wavelength \(\lambda\) , the minimum potential difference \(V\) is recorded.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[303, 682, 650, 698]]<|/det|>
Question 2 continues on the next page.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 572, 90]]<|/det|> 
It is suggested that \(V\) and \(\lambda\) are related by the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[443, 100, 551, 127]]<|/det|>

\[\frac{hc}{\lambda} = B + eV\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 135, 875, 167]]<|/det|>

where \(c\) is the speed of light in a vacuum, \(e\) is the elementary charge, \(h\) is the Planck constant and \(B\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 182, 146, 199]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 182, 875, 214]]<|/det|>
